transcripts.text: Okay, well hi everyone.  We've got an exciting program for you today.  I'm going to tell you about that here in a moment, but just to show you where we are, I'm going to get our videographer to sort of turn around, and you'll be able to see, oh look, in Kentucky.  It's not on the mountains of Ararat, it's in Kentucky, and it's the life-size Noah's Ark.  So we're at Ararat Ridge Zoo and I know kids love these animal programs and we have a really, really special program today.  We like to do some different things.  I mean, we show you animals on occasion just to for you to understand from a design perspective and a biblical worldview perspective, something about the animals we have here at Ararat Ridge Zoo and also the Creation Museum.  And then we also want to do a lot of behind the scenes stuff too to tell you what goes on, to look after all these animals and to enable a zoo like this to operate.  But today, well, have you ever seen on television, they have those vet programs like the incredible Dr.  Pohl.  They have those sort of exciting programs where they follow the veterinarian around and he goes and there's a sick cow and then there's a sick horse or something or other and then he has to go.  you know, deliver some animal or whatever it happens to be.  Sarah Jo, you know what I'm talking about, right?  Yes, I do.  Okay, so you're going to be our Dr.  Pohl today.
Yes, not quite up to those standards.

Well, we do have a veterinarian that comes out here and you work with, but you have vet experience too, don't you?  Yes, I'm a licensed vet tech.  So we're going to show you how they deal with animals that might need to go to the dentist or need, I don't know, go to a massage therapist or have a sore tail or sick in some ways.  So you're going to find this interesting.  So I'm going to let Sarah Jo lead us here.  Yeah.  So we have, what, a couple of donkeys here?
Yeah, these are our two mini donkeys or Mediterranean donkeys.
And then I'd like Mr.  Ed, you know, you probably don't know Mr.  Ed.
No.
No, you're not old enough.  The program I used to watch when I was a teenager, you know, Mr.  Ed, the talking horse, he could tell you when he was sick and all that.  Anyway, they don't do that.
No, not quite.  They do let you know when you're late for dinner time.  They like to talk a lot then.
All right, well, tell us what we're going to do today.

Yeah, so we have Sheba and Jezebel.  So these are kind of our high-maintenance donkeys, our little mini donkeys.  So Sheba over there has a condition called founder.  So what a lot of people don't know is that donkeys actually have, and all equine, have a bone inside their hoof.  And sometimes that bone starts to rotate, so it's not parallel with the hoof anymore, and then that causes some pain.  So what that's called is foundered.  So Sheba has foundered before.
So she's affected by sin.
Yeah, exactly.
And it was our sin and Adam that caused that.  Yep.  So you're responsible for why they have...

Yep, and I'm helping to take care of her because of that, because that is our responsibility.  So I'm actually going to pass this on to Brittany so she can show you guys what we do with Ms.  Sheba if Jezebel will hop out of the way.  So on top of different medications and different specific diet for Sheba, she also gets acupuncture.  So what that does is help promote blood flow to that area to help it grow.  And I can take Ms.  Jeze.  so she's out of the way.  Come here, Jeze.  Good girl.  So like I said, the acupuncture is gonna help her heal from that foundered situation.  But when we first introduced acupuncture to Sheba, she wasn't a huge fan of it.  So what we do is some desensitizing.  So Brittany has a toothpick in her hand and she's just gonna lightly poke her everywhere where the acupuncturist would put those needles in.  So he puts those needles in and then they stay there for 25 minutes.  And that stimulates that area to bring that blood flow and relieve some pain.  So right now we're not causing any pain at all.  She's just getting a couple toothpicks to her feet.  and then she gets treats.
So the acupuncture actually works?

It does.  It's amazing.  So when she first found her a couple years ago, she could hardly walk.  It was pretty sad to see.  We do a lot of therapy with her.  We even trained her to soak her front feet in an ice bath, and that helps promote healing to that area.  So since she started the acupuncture, she's walking great.  So we just do maintenance on her, and she gets to see the acupuncturist once a month.
I have a sore finger.  Can you do acupuncture on me?

I'm not trained on that.  We'll see if our vet would like to do that.  Our other donkey on this side is Miss Jezebel, and she's also a little high maintenance because she has a thyroid issue.  I don't know if you've ever heard of a donkey with a thyroid issue, but this is the one.  So what that means is she gets a thyroid medication in her feed morning and evening.  It's very time sensitive.  And then she gets her blood taken every once in a while to make sure that she's all nice and healthy and her thyroid levels are staying good.  So these guys are getting really top-notch care and getting spoiled rotten.
They're nearly as high maintenance as I am.  Yeah.  As you get older, you get high maintenance when it comes to medical things, right?
So Miss Jessie sometimes will smile.  Do you want to smile?  Will you show us a smile?
She doesn't smile.
Maybe, yeah, there's those pretty teeth.
You call that a smile?  Okay, I want all the kids to go in there and tell me, was that a smile or not?  Can you do it again?  Yeah, let's see.  Okay, let's see.

Can you do a smile again?  Smell puff.  Show us your teeth.  She said, now you made me camera shy.  Said it wasn't a real smile.  She did it before.  You want this?  Can you do a smile again?  No.  Almost.  That was worth a shot.  Oh, Sheba smiled.  Sheba might smile for us, too.  Here you go.  Share your teeth.  Yeah, so you can see those lips, how they use those to grab onto different grasses and things.  It's pretty good.
Okay, so now I've seen two donkeys smile.
Yes.
My day is made.
All right, well, I'm going to let Miss Jezebel here go, and we are going to go show how we take care of one of our other animals inside.
All right, let's go and have a look at another animal that has a medical condition.
Bye, Sheba and Jezebel.

We'll see if we can follow our Dr.  Sarah Jo.  Well, she's not doctor, but today she's honorary doctor.  Okay, honorary Dr.  Sarah Jo today.  Okay, this is like one of those TV programs where they're going to go to the next sick animal.
Yep, one animal to another.  So all of our animals are scheduled for their medications.  Coming out through here?  Yeah, so every day.
What's down in here, Sarah Jo?
Oh, we have our red tegu in there.  Can you guys see him?  Is he hanging out?  That is Jethro.
I sort of see him at the front here.

Yeah.  So you guys can see, too, he's got quite the setup.  These guys require really high humidity.  So he's got a humidifier hooked up, and it's constantly pumping that humidity to him.  So in here, we've got a couple of our goats.  Oh, and Candice is going to talk to us.  So in here is Miss Neftali and her daughter, Castle.  So Neftali is this little black and white one, and then Castle is actually bigger than her, even though she's her daughter.
I was going to say, that looks like the daughter there, but this is the daughter.

Yep.  Yeah, so Castle is a little bit bigger than her.  Castle's actually the first baby born here at the Ararat Ridge Zoo, so she's very, very sweet.  So Neftali over here is a pygmy goat.  She's a really small breed of goat, and it's pretty common.  That's very nice for the camera.  So it's pretty common that these guys will develop some stiffness in their joints as they're growing.  So what she gets is a daily medication.  It's basically like animal ibuprofen.  But one of the things we want to do is have all of our animals participate in their own vet care.  So this tastes like apples, and she'll usually go for it right away.  There's some new people in here, so she might be a little weary, but we'll see.  Hey, Miss Neftali, would you like your medicine?  No?  Here.  Good girl.  And see, she just grabs onto that herself and takes it.  And that's really easy for us to be able to take care of her in that way.
So that's like ibuprofen, you said?
Yep, for animals.
So it stops the pain?
Yep.  So it helps her get a little bit more mobile so she can run around.
So you can tell the difference when you use that?
Absolutely, yes.  And because she is on this as well, we constantly monitor her blood work and make sure all of her organs are functioning properly on that as well.  So yep, she gets this medication.
So pygmy goats.  So they've probably got some sort of mutation that causes them to be pygmy, and that creates problems, right?
Yeah, yep.

Hey, have you ever thought about this?  Mutations, when you see them in animals, they always cause problems, right?  Yet according to evolutionists, mutations over millions of years improved everything and evolved one kind or another.  It doesn't make sense, does it?
Right.  So now we're going to head back inside and take a look at some of our reptile care that we've done for these guys in the past.
You mean you actually have reptiles that have medical issues?

Oh, we do.  Yes, we do.  Unfortunately, it happens to all the animals.  The entire world and all of its inhabitants are affected by that sin.  So we do have to make sure we're taking care of all of them the best way possible.  So we've got some previous cases in here.  we wanted to show you guys.  All right.  So first up is Mr.  Tannen, and he's a bearded dragon.  He's from where you are.
From Australia.

Yeah.  So Tannen, a lot of you guys might have dogs and cats, and some of you may even have to have a dental for your dog or cat.  So their teeth, they don't brush their teeth every day like we do, and sometimes they get that buildup on their teeth, and that can lead to gum disease, which isn't good for them.  That can travel through their body and have more problems throughout their body.  So this little guy here had some pretty serious problems with his teeth.  They were very, very dirty, and he was kind of getting an infection in those gums.  So he had a dental.  Not very many parent and dragons have a dental cleaning, so he was anesthetized, had his teeth cleaned out really well.  But now to keep that from happening again, we actually kind of brush his teeth once a week.

You know what's amazing to me?  People who, when we're open again, of course, which we pray will be soon, people will come in here, come to the zoo, see the animals.  You'll see some of the animal programs and the animal actor stage.  And you take animals around and show people as well.  They wouldn't know all the care that goes on behind the scenes.

There is so much that goes into taking care of all of these animals.  We have a system that makes a checklist of all of the medical care we need to do for all the animals every day.  And it is an all-day task to make sure every animal is getting their medication and their treatments that they need.  So yeah, these guys get top-notch care.  So Brittany's going to show us how, if he wants to sit still for us, I might have to hold him, set down the mic for a second.  So what we do is use a solution that our vet was given to us.  And instead of a toothbrush, he's got a little cotton swab, like what we would clean our ears with.  And she's just going to have him open his little mouth.  And she's just going to swab that gun line.
Have you noticed that they get used to this?

Yeah, yeah.  He actually doesn't mind this too much.  Like you can see, he's kind of wiggling his head.  It doesn't have the best taste in the world, but it does keep his teeth nice and clean.  So she got the one side, and I'm going to hold his little back end for the next side.
Well, I have never seen a bearded dragon get his teeth cleaned before.
There we go.
If there's any Australians watching, have you ever seen an Australian bearded dragon get his teeth cleaned?

Yeah.  And he is an awesome sport for this.  He only has to do it once a week.  So he does really great for it.  And next up we have another bearded dragon.  So this one is a male, and this is Zakana.  She is a female.  So some of you with pet bearded dragons, if you have a female, you know that sometimes they lay eggs.  And Miss Zakana had a reoccurring issue of laying too many eggs.  Oh, really?  And what can happen is they can get a blockage, which will make them really sick.  And when they're laying those eggs that constantly, they're basically immunosuppressed.  So they're more prone to developing other issues because of that.  So what we did with her is we actually had her spayed.  So just like you have your dog and cat spayed, she was spayed.  And if Rudy wants to pick her up and show you guys, she's soaking in a bath right now.  but you can actually see this line on her tummy.  It's all healed now, but this is where the vet had to go in, and she had surgery, and they found lots and lots of eggs in there.  She was pretty egg-bound, got that out, and now she's doing perfectly fine, which is awesome.
You actually had a vet operate.

We did.  Yes, we did.  We work with several vets here at Ridge Zoo.  They all have different specialties.  So one works with the large animals, one works with all the reptiles, another works with all of the birds.  They all have different specialties to make sure that they're all getting taken care of in the best way possible.
So the vet anesthetized both of these guys and then did the operation.  And when they come out of that, can you tell they're not very happy?

Well, it takes several, it takes a long time for bearded dragons and other reptiles to wake up from anesthesia because their metabolism is so slow.  Yeah.  So dogs and cats, they can wake up a lot faster.  These guys, it takes quite some time.  So they need that heat because they're ectotherms.  They need to raise their own body temperature.  And then usually they're put in an oxygen tank.  So that way they're getting lots of oxygen and that helps them wake up.  But since Zecana was spayed, she is a whole new animal.  She is doing fantastic.  She eats a ton.  But now she can't have little ones.  Yes, exactly.  And also we're not finding tons of eggs in her enclosure every day.
So have we had any of our reptiles breed here at all?

No, we have not.  Nope.  That takes a large toll on them when you're asking that much of them.  You have to increase their diet.  There's a lot of things that go into that.  All these guys have to make sure you're supplementing their calcium.  Lots and lots goes into that.  So what do they do in the wild?  Well, mainly their diet out in the wild would help supplement them with that.  And if they're in breeding season, they're going to change how much they're eating and everything.  but most of these guys are separated because that's how they would live in the wild.  they would only come together to breed and since they're not doing that they're all kind of living separately.  but obviously they can be side by side and be just fine.  the bearded dragons as you know when they're upset their beard will turn completely black and they'll inflate it.  so you can see both these guys are really chill right now.  they're very well used to this vet care.  if they were not happy with us they could run away or do whatever they want to but they're very happy to chill right here.
Well, that is incredible.  It is fascinating to get all this behind-the-scenes info.  I didn't realize all this went on.
Every day.
That you actually operated on bearded dragons.  So what else have we got here?

We've got one last one for you here, and Miss Zilla is actually one of our original animals to the zoo.  So if you guys can see her, Miss Zilla is a leopard gecko, and she doesn't look like most other leopard geckos because of her tail.  So these guys normally have a really long tail like you might be able to see in this picture.  and they store all their fat in that tail.  but it's a really cool adaptation because if a predator were to grab onto that tail they can actually voluntarily drop it and a lot goes into that.  vasoconstriction has to happen.  so that way they don't bleed out that undetached tail can continue to wiggle around for a good 30 minutes to keep the predator distracted while they make a quick getaway.  So that's really awesome.  They can do that up to five times.  Now, Mozilla unfortunately came to us with an infection in her tail, and we were trying everything.  She was even getting antibiotic injections, which on an animal this small is pretty hard to do.  But we tried everything we could to save that tail, and unfortunately, we just couldn't.  So the same vet who did our surgery on our other two bearded dragons anesthetized this tiny little leopard gecko and had to amputate that tail because it was infected.  And now since that tail was artificially removed, the vet wasn't sure if the tail would regrow.  But you can see she's actually got a little nubbin of a tail growing back.  So it's not exactly the same as a normal tail would be.  She's still storing a lot of her fat in there.  But yeah, it's probably going to stop right there.  It's been like that for about two years now.  Yeah, so it's reached its limit.
So this is a unique gait guide.

Very unique gecko, yes.  And a surgery on an animal that small is really difficult.  And then you have to take into account all of the aftercare that goes into that.  So she was getting daily soaks and warm water to help promote the blood flow to the area.  We were doing antibiotic ointment on the back.  We had to take sutures out of her.  But she's doing fantastic now.  She loves coming out and meeting the children and doing encounters just like this.

And that's one of the things that we should tell people is that when you come to Ararat Rezou, you can go and see the animals that are on display.  They're exhibited out there.  But we have a lot of animals behind the scenes.  You call them ambassador animals?  Yes.  And we have workshops for kids.  For instance, we have overnights at the Ark and the Creation Museum.  and then you have other special programs where they'll see these ambassador animals.  and now with our new animal actor stage here too you'll be able to use some of the ambassador animals there as well.  so there's a lot of animals that you won't necessarily see when you come to our at ridge zoo but if you go to the workshops or the animal actor stage you'll see them.

Yeah, I mean we've got about over 20 animals just in this room alone, and this is behind the scenes area.  And the reason we do that is because all these guys are pretty small, so coming out and working for them, we want to make sure we have them on a rotation, so everyone kind of gets a day off, just like we get a day off from work every once in a while.

Well, there you are.  You don't have to go to television to see on the cable channels one of these vet programs.  You can come to Answers in Genesis and see those sort of programs right here.  Well, that was fascinating.  So we looked at the two donkeys, and then a goat that had a medical problem, and then two bearded dragons.  They both have medical problems.  And then a gecko.
Yep.  It was completely on the mend now.
What species of gecko is that?

She's a leopard gecko.  So you can tell by all of her little spots.  And then when she hunts, she raises her little tail, her little leftover tail in the air, and she wiggles it around before she pounces.
So you must have a sort of spreadsheet somewhere with all the different medicines you have to give.

Everything's on an actually online system that we use.  So all of us can access it from our phones.  So we can all check off medications as we're giving them to the animals.  So everyone is very on top of all of that medication and everyone's trained to give them all.

Just like nurses in hospitals.  Yep, exactly.  Make sure they get the medicine to the right place and the right person.  Well, there we go.  Hope you enjoyed this behind the scenes with... Honorary veterinary Sarah Jo today.  She has had vet experience.  You're a vet tech, right?
I'm a licensed vet tech.  Yes, I am.
So there we are.  You can be a licensed vet tech and work at Ridge Zoo one day.  Absolutely.
I'll take the help.  There's lots to do.
Hope you enjoyed the program.
